Have you ever had that awkward moment, just after jumping into a new large codebase, when you find everything wild and chaotic?

I know, it‚Äôs hard to avoid thinking: ‚ÄúThis is a mess. How could anyone maintain this stuff?‚Äù

If you‚Äôve been into software long enough, I‚Äôm 100% sure you‚Äôve had this kind of feeling.

But over time, I‚Äôve learned something:

‚Ü≥ When really complex systems work for real customers, even if they work imperfectly, that‚Äôs not something to take lightly.

The very fact that it has worked and survived the test of time is a huge achievement!

Because complex systems are always messy from the inside out.

SIDE NOTE: You know what I mean, the complexity of software is such a fascinating thing, isn‚Äôt it? üòÅ

This complexity is the price we pay for solving real problems at scale.

There‚Äôs no way to escape from it.

We don‚Äôt eliminate complexity, we just move it around and hide it with abstractions. 

That‚Äôs why I hesitate before touching legacy code that has quietly done its job for years.

Now I only change old, battle-proven code when I absolutely must. Seriously.

If you're in doubt, remember Chesterton‚Äôs Fence: 

‚Ü≥ ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt tear down a fence until you understand why it was built.‚Äù

In other words: ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt change what you don‚Äôt understand!‚Äù

I know it's hard this days, with #AI tools, it‚Äôs easier than ever to refactor or rewrite code. The bar to start making changes has lowered down significantly. But there‚Äôs a danger in how quickly we forget why something exists. For example, AI doesn‚Äôt know that a function was built around a legal constraint, a performance hack, or a hard-learned production failure.

Many disasters in software don‚Äôt come from bad intentions. They come from lack of context and/or ignoring history.

New leaders often arrive, find things ‚Äúuseless‚Äù or ‚Äúbroken,‚Äù and want to delete or change them without appreciating the journey it took other devs to get there.

So when entering into a new codebase, respect wildlife like a nice guest in your neighbor's house. Because we won‚Äôt be able to fully grasp the intricacies of an ecosystem at the first glance, and that‚Äôs why we tread lightly.

Let me said it again, we should stop pretending complexity can be removed. I've seen so many failed attempts into this direction... I can't count.

Let‚Äôs accept complexity, that‚Äôs all. 

Good engineers make sure they understand the past before trying to mess around with the present.

Let‚Äôs respect wildlife, for our own survival! üêü

Many of us once read TAOCP and believed that coding and algorithms were a form of art that couldn‚Äôt be automated.

But we were wrong.

What I once saw as a unique human craft is now the next target for assembly line automation.

Turns out that programming is just advanced pattern-matching, and #LLMs are extremely good at it.

#AI doesn‚Äôt just generate code that runs, it‚Äôs already getting better than most human developers when looking at code quality.

But I‚Äôm not disillusioned about the future of software engineering, I‚Äôm just waking up to the shift‚Ä¶

Because this isn‚Äôt just another bump in abstraction, like when we moved from assembly to higher-level PLs, I think it‚Äôs a paradigm shift.

We‚Äôre no longer writing most code from scratch, and if you still see yourself as a ‚Äúcode writer,‚Äù you‚Äôll be left behind.

I believe the true winners in this new era will be those who understand how software should work, not just how to ‚Äúmake it work once.‚Äù

Because writing code isn‚Äôt the hard part anymore. That problem has been effectively solved, much like how machine translation was solved with Transformers.

Now, the real challenge is:
‚Üí Know what to build.
‚Üí Know how it should work.
‚Üí Know how to make it evolve.

For example, I can prompt an LLM to write code that ingests messages from a Kafka topic and stores them in a PostgreSQL DB.

But I still need to:
‚Üí Handle message deduplication and idempotency.
‚Üí Implement retries with exponential backoff on database failures.
‚Üí Design the storage schema to accommodate evolving message formats.

Clear thinking about design, data, performance, and maintenance is becoming the most valuable skill in tech.

So no, I‚Äôm not walking away from code.

I‚Äôm doubling down on software design, distributed systems, and everything that makes software robust, maintainable, and scalable.

Cause if we know what we're doing, AI won't replace us, it'll just make us 100x more valuable.

I love knobs, buttons, and PBT keycaps.
There‚Äôs something deeply satisfying about that tactile feedback, ... like my fingers are really feeling the machines. 

But two decades ago, we started replacing our lovely physical UX by something else (thanks, Apple for the iPhone). 
Everything shifted to flat, glowing digital keyboards in the name of "productivity," "more features," and "more screen space."

Now these screens are everywhere, even where it doesn't make any sense.
Touchscreens on fridges, on my front door, on cars (thanks, Tesla). 
Even TVs have on-screen keyboards?!

Oh, I have to mention my Samsung TV here.
It forces me to search using a remote with no physical letters that only moves in four directions‚Ä¶ typing one letter at a time ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

But now #AI has arrived, finally.
#LLMs promise to change everything.
And the industry now wants to replace the digital keyboard with voice.

But sure, we‚Äôve heard this before: Siri, Alexa, Google Home. Do you remember?
They never really took off.

So is natural language finally the future of UX?

Honestly‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt think so.

Why?

Because it's inefficient, limited, and inconvenient.

‚Üí¬†It‚Äôs inefficient because we think at thousands of words per minute but can only speak ~150. And unlike typing, you can‚Äôt easily go back and edit your words when speaking. That makes natural language interactions slow, error-prone, and frustrating.

‚Üí¬†It‚Äôs limited because it's lossy and ambiguous. Structured commands are clear. Language is fuzzy. You say one thing, the machine hears another. And you enter a cycle of clarifications.

‚Üí¬†It‚Äôs inconvenient because saying ‚ÄúOpen a new tab‚Äù out loud when ‚åòT does it instantly is nonsense. Not to mention that this doesn't work in public spaces. 

So no, #LLMs won‚Äôt replace the mouse and keyboard.
It doesn't matter how good the models will get.

When we‚Äôll ditch them?
If you ask me, I think that'll happen when #AI can finally read our thoughts.

But that‚Äôs another story.

For now, I‚Äôll keep enjoying the satisfying clack clack of my hand-modded mechanical keyboard ‚å®Ô∏è

Let me tell you a quick story about programming, chess, and what's been wrong with coding interviews for decades:

In my 1st year of grad school, I heard about programming contests. They sounded exciting, but I didn‚Äôt solved any problem (I didn't know how to code in 2009).

By 2nd year, I jumped in, competed in a local ACM-ICPC tournament and got hooked.

Next year, I was solving problem after problem on online judges (got 1,000+ correct submissions) and went to the regionals. It felt like leveling up in a video game.

But something changed.

The deeper I went, the more I realized: this wasn‚Äôt fun anymore. It was like ches: to really excel, you have to dedicate your life to it (I love chess, btw). 

That killed the joy.

So I stepped away.

Years later, I entered the job market, and boom! Coding interviews (especially in big tech) were all about solving those kinds of ADA problems live, under extreme pressure.

It felt familiar. Too familiar‚Ä¶

But in this case there's a huge problem:

Solving algorithm puzzles in 45 mins has nothing to do with writing clean, maintainable software in the real world.

Worse, the system is really broken:

‚Ü≥ It rewards people who‚Äôve memorized patterns, not those who solve real problems.
‚Ü≥ It filters out brilliant engineers who haven‚Äôt ‚ÄúLeetcoded enough.‚Äù
‚Ü≥ It creates a test that‚Äôs easy to fail.

I understand that this test style is scalable, but I've seen senior engineers with PhDs and successful OSS projects spending weeks practicing LeetCode problems just to get past the first interview screen.

Putting that much energy into riddles wasn‚Äôt that bad 20 years ago. But the world has changed a lot since then.

Today‚Äôs #LLMs can solve most ACM-ICPC problems in seconds.

I don't really see how this could be a good way to test the value of professionals.

Today I read about undetectable apps that feeds GPT-powered answers during LeetCode-style online interviews, like the one created by Roy Lee.

So the system will collapse under its own weight (at least for its online mode). But honestly... I'm happy about it.

It‚Äôs finally time to kill programming-contest-style interviews for good.

So what should we do instead?

Here are some alternatives that I believe actually reflect real skills:

‚Ü≥ Give a real-world business problem. Ask the candidate to design and implement a solution from scratch. Discuss trade-offs, architecture, and impact.
‚Ü≥ Show messy, buggy, insecure code. Ask what‚Äôs wrong, what‚Äôs risky, and how they‚Äôd fix it.
‚Ü≥ Give raw data. Ask them to build something that adds or creates business value.

The whole point should be to simulate the real job. Because the real job lives in the real world. And in the real world, there is #AI, whether we want it or not.

So, let‚Äôs stop testing people on fantasy skills.

If you have a different idea, let me know üôÇ

P.S. I wrote a blog post many years ago about how I trained for ACM-ICPC contests (LLMs didn‚Äôt exist back then), here's it ‚Üí¬†https://lnkd.in/dqhBvVEh
